If thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s an album cover that epitomises its contents more than the new Guitar Wolf disc, I have not seen it. With guitar slung, black leather clad and devil horns salute in tow, there is no mistaking what this is all about. Dirty, filthy, fucked up garage band Ã¢â‚¬ËœLOCK and LOLLÃ¢â‚¬â„¢(sic). Err..message to Nigel of Spinal Tap, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve found another band that turns it all the way to eleven!!

This is my first experience with the Japanese three-piece known as Guitar Wolf. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been at it since 1987 churning out seven local side full lengths that IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve never heard or more significantly, never had access to. If it wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t for a very influential Japanese based mate of mine, this one would have passed me by also. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m glad for the recommendation. This disc sounds like nails down a chalk board; a severely demented racket thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll have you reeling and begging for mercy. This is about as unbridled as it gets folks. If youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re sick of the safe, homogenised, no room for error style of hard rock, Guitar Wolf are its complete antithesis. Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is all about putting the danger back in rock n roll (which apparently is what theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve done for the past 18 years). You want a rock n roll band with a pulse? Fucking hell, Guitar WolfÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sits at 180 bpm! 

When I think of sweaty, alcohol fuelled 70Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s style guitar rock; I think Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Ramones, The MC5, The Hellacopters, John Spencer Blues Explosion, The fucking Stooges!!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a clutch of other underground garage bands that Guitar Wolf draw upon, but the point is these guys bathe in the same filthy, cockroach infested sess pool. Like the aforementioned masters and armed with a phenomenally primal sound Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is guaranteed to cause you and everyone else within a three block vicinity some damage. I knew this disc would rock, but I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really expect such a pummelling of the senses. 

Sonically, Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is deliberately lo-fi, raw, rough and visceral. There is simply nothing clean about this disc at all. Subversiveness is its aim. Think The Stooges Ã¢â‚¬ËœRaw PowerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ meets Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe MC5Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ as a template and youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got an idea on just where this is coming from. It actually sounds so fucking crap its good. Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ squeals and shrieks with a raging barrage of over-distorted amplification that will have even the most hardened trash-rock fan bleeding from the ears. Still, the vitality and urgency that this album displays is hard to ignore, even if it sounds like the same track repeated seventeen times.

Of course, Ã¢â‚¬ËœGuitar WolfÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s most interesting aspect, for me at least, is that they are Japanese. Musically, they may have the same influences as their Western peers, but thematically and lyrically thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s always a different take. With Guitar Wolf, it is frontman SeijiÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s performance that stands out. His Ã¢â‚¬ËœONE-TWO-THREE-FOURÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ banter is more a homage than a rip-off and his wild, exuberant delivery takes this album to another level. Of course, everything here follows a Japanese verse, English chorus format. It is notable that the lyric booklet contains all songs in English translation, however as some have already pointed out, considering the manic delivery of Seiji, they would make no sense either way. Even the local Japanese fans would have trouble deciphering what goes down on this disc. All you really need to know is that Guitar Wolf write about is the bare essentials of life Ã¢â‚¬â€œ leather, rock n roll, motorbikes and girls. Yeah, BABY!!

Guitar Wolf makes no apologies for their garage rock single mindedness. They couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t give a flying fruitcake about anything released post-1983; it just doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t count. Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is all about STYLE over substance Ã¢â‚¬â€œ it matters not that the track listing is rendered useless by its lack of diversity, the point is its celebration of an attitude and lifestyle that is decades old. Dumb/stupid, fast/furious unrestrained Rock n Roll - ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the charm of Ã¢â‚¬ËœLoverockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢.

*Note, just weeks ago on March 30th, Billy the Ã¢â‚¬ËœBass WolfÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ (Hideaki Sekiguchi)died suddenly of a heart attack. He was 38 years old. Guitar WolfÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s status is now in limbo.

The band starred in a gruesome, romantic japanese zombie movie called Wild Zero - it was upped here on piratebay a wee while ago I believe. You might want to check it out if you dig this music.
